2001.events: Inclusion of Hepatitis B Vaccine in National Immunization Program
2001.description: Policy Update: The hepatitis B vaccine was included in the National Immunization Program (NIP) for all infants at birth, 2, 4, and 6 months. Goal: To provide early protection against hepatitis B and reduce the incidence of the disease.

2003.description: Initiative: A catch-up vaccination program for adolescents aged 10-13 who had not been vaccinated as infants. Impact: Improved vaccination coverage among older children, ensuring broader immunity in the population.

2005.description: Policy: Expansion of vaccination programs to include hepatitis A and B vaccination for Indigenous children in high-risk areas. Reason: Higher rates of hepatitis B infection in Indigenous communities warranted targeted interventions.

2008.events: Hepatitis A and B Vaccination for High-Risk Adults
2008.description: Initiative: Introduction of hepatitis A and B vaccination for high-risk adult populations, including healthcare workers, people with chronic liver disease, and those with high-risk behaviors. Objective: To reduce the transmission and impact of hepatitis among vulnerable populations.

2010.description: Strategy: Development of a national strategy focused on prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of hepatitis B. Goals: Increase vaccination rates, improve early diagnosis, and enhance access to care for people with hepatitis B.

2011.description: Policy Recommendation: Recommendation for pregnant women to be screened for hepatitis B and vaccinated if at risk, to prevent mother-to-child transmission. Impact: Reduction in perinatal transmission of hepatitis B.

2014.description: Policy: Reinforcement of the importance of administering the hepatitis B vaccine within 24 hours of birth for all newborns. Goal: To further reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission.

2015.description: Policy: Requirement for children to be fully immunized (including hepatitis B) to receive family assistance payments. Effect: Increased vaccination compliance and coverage.

2016.description: Update: Introduction of a combined hepatitis A and B vaccine for infants in high-risk areas, simplifying the vaccination schedule. Goal: Improve vaccination rates and reduce hepatitis incidence in high-risk populations.

2018.description: Strategy: Update of the national strategy to address ongoing challenges in hepatitis B prevention and management. Focus: Enhance vaccination efforts, improve surveillance, and support research and innovation in hepatitis B treatment.

2019.events: Hepatitis B Management in Primary Care
2019.description: Initiative: Increased emphasis on the role of primary care providers in managing hepatitis B, including vaccination, testing, and treatment. Impact: Improved integration of hepatitis B management into primary healthcare services.

2020.description: Adjustment: Efforts to maintain routine immunization schedules, including hepatitis B, despite pandemic-related disruptions. Measures: Public health campaigns emphasizing the importance of continuing vaccinations.

2021.description: Policy: Continued emphasis on vaccinating high-risk adults, including healthcare workers and people with chronic conditions. Impact: Sustained high coverage and reduced hepatitis B transmission.

2022.description: Focus: Maintaining high vaccination coverage, addressing vaccine misinformation, and ensuring robust surveillance systems. Initiatives: Ongoing public health campaigns and targeted vaccination programs to prevent hepatitis B.
